occurrences.line_text: And make me loath this life, still longing for to die.
Of brothers prayse, to you eke longs his loue.
There shall a sparke of fire, which hath long-while
The same longwhile I bore, and therewithall
Ne looke for entertainement, where none was:
With gentle blandishment and louely looke,
And that dread Lyons looke her cast in deadly hew.
His looke was sterne, and seemed still to threat
With loftie eyes, halfe loth to looke so low,
Does care for looke of liuing creatures eye.
And her darke griesly looke them much dismay;
With chaunge of feare, to see the Lyon looke so grim.
Then casting vp a deadly looke, full low,
So vp he let him rise, who with grim looke
Sterne was his looke, and full of stomacke vaine,
Sterne was their looke, like wild amazed steares,
In which when as he greedily did looke;
She ouerhent, nought moued with her piteous looke.
Might looke, that maketh euery creature glad,
As pale and wan as ashes was his looke,
Yet being men they did vnmanly looke,
Large were his limbes, and terrible his looke,
With heauie looke and lumpish pace, that plaine
And with fell looke and hollow deadly gaze
Another Florimell, in shape and looke
To looke on her faire face, and marke her snowy skin.
As if he could haue kild him with his looke,
To looke adowne, or vpward to the hight:
Who therewith somewhat starting, vp gan looke,
Of chearefull looke and louely to behold;
Which who so list looke backe to former ages,
And euerie looke was coy, and wondrous quaint,
Then life to hazard for faire Ladies looke;
Then looke to whom she voluntarie came,
With one sterne looke so daunted, that no ioy
Bad them not looke for better entertayne;
Durst not the sternnesse of his looke abide,
So as I entred, I did backeward looke,
That with thy smyling looke doest pacifie
Ne euer once did looke vp from her desse,
For who so list into the heauens looke,
Whom at the first he ghessed by his looke,
But looke who does dissent from this my read,
And looke what surplus did of each remaine,
And looke then how much it doth ouerflow,
Doe hide themselues from her astonying looke,
All suddenly, ere one can looke aside,
The horse in hand, within his mouth to looke:
He to her lept with deadly dreadfull looke,
Looke vp at last, and wake thy dulled spirit,
Her wand did moue with amiable looke,
But by the change of her vnchearefull looke,
Where is that dreadfull manly looke? where be
And euer round about he cast his looke.
She gan take hart, and looke vp ioyfully:
And sternely him beheld with grim and ghastly looke.
A dreadfull feend, with fowle deformed looke,
Gins to looke vp, and with fresh wonted grace
With dreadfull looke he Artegall beheld,
With her dull eyes did seeme to looke askew,
But put away proud looke, and vsage sterne,
Gnashing his grinded teeth with griesly looke,
And bound him fast: Tho when he vp did looke,
To chaunge the manner of his loftie looke;
Of that sunne-shine, that makes them looke askew.
Looke how the Crowne, which Ariadne wore
For they for better hyre did shortly looke,
And looked in: his glistring armor made
This said, adowne he looked to the ground,
And looked all about, if she might spy
And looked forth, to weet, if true indeede
Eftsoones forth looked from the highest spire
Which drawing backe, he looked euermore
That Capons courage: yet he looked grim,
But when she looked vp, to weet, what wight
Ne euer looked backe for good or ill,
And neuer looked, who behind him was,
He looked round about with sterne disdaine;
He looked backe, and her aduizing well,
But when as long he looked had in vaine,
Ne storming Humber, though he looked stout;
And made them stoupe, that looked earst so hie.
There as she looked long, at last she spide
To looken backe; his eyes be fixt before.
To looken, whether it were night or day:
So that it to the looker appertaynd;
The lookers on, and lowd to him gan call
So hid in lockes and waues from lookers theft,
That fild the lookers on attonce with ruth and wonder.
But nathelesse whilst all the lookers on
Which when as all the lookers on beheld,
Into the lookers hart, and killeth farre away.
And she coy lookes: so dainty they say maketh derth.
And euer by her lookes conceiued her intent.
All night she thinks too long, and often lookes for light.
And learned had to loue with secret lookes,
And sternly lookes at him, who not a pin
But wordes, and lookes, and sighes she did abhore,
And when him list the prouder lookes subdew,
With lookes full lowly cast, and gate full slow,
Whose sober lookes her wisedome well descride:
And if by lookes one may the mind aread,
For Guyons lookes, but scornefull eyglaunce at him shot.
Some framd faire lookes, glancing like euening lights,
But with sterne lookes, and stomachous disdaine,
Of Death, and like him lookes in dreadfull hew,
With nought but ghastly lookes him answered,
With speaking lookes, that close embassage bore,
In lofty lookes to hide an humble mind,
With ghastly lookes and dreadfull drerihed;
And coy lookes tempring with loose dalliance;
And eke vnto her lookes a law she made,
Onely few ruefull lookes vnto her sent,
Armies of louely lookes, and speeches wise,
Nought fear'd the childe his lookes, ne yet his threats,
Which daily may to thy sweete lookes repayre,
By signes, by lookes, and all his other gests.
Through tempering of her words & lookes by wondrous skill.
Yet were her words and lookes but false and fayned,
His lookes were dreadfull, and his fiery eies
As if he with his lookes would all men terrifie.
That he his lookes despised, and his boast dispraized.
His layes, his loues, his lookes she did them all despize.
Looking to heauen; for earth she did disdayne,
And looking louely, and oft sighing sore,
Eft looking backe would faine haue runne away;
And looking downe, saw many damned wights,
And looking vp, when as his shield he lakt,
Nought but her louely face she for his looking left.
Whose image she had seene in Venus looking glas.
A looking glasse, right wondrously aguiz'd,
Glauncing vnwares in charmed looking glas,
And though oft looking backward, well she vewd,
Looking with myld aspect vpon the earth,
But he him selfe sate looking still askaunce,
Bigge looking like a doughtie Doucepere,
Still fled he forward, looking backward still,
Vnder his eyebrowes looking still askaunce;
He looking lompish and full sullein sad,
Trembling in heart, and looking pale and wan,
And looking round about, like one dismaid,
Yet looking round about him none could see;
That in his face, as in a looking glasse,
And looking sterne, still ouer him did stand,
She looking backe, espies that griesly wight
And looking after long, did marke which way she straid.
Th'one forward looking, th'other backeward bent,
Low looking dales, disloignd from common gaze;
All looking on, and like astonisht staring,
There looking forth, shee in her heart did find
Forth of her window as she looking lay,
That could deceiue one looking in his face;
Where she with her two sonnes did looking stand,
Tho looking vp vnto the cry to lest,
Looking at that same Carle with count'nance grim,
Where looking all about, where he mote fynd
Still looking after him, that did him chace;
Then looking round about, and seeing nought,
Looking each houre into deathes mouth to fall,
And this misseeming hew your manly looks doth marre?
Hee turnd againe, and chearefull looks as earst did shew.
That such proud looks would make her praysed more;
With looks, with words, with gifts he oft her wowed;
She lookt about, and seeing one in mayle
Lookt for her knight, who far away was fled,
Full fast she fled, ne euer lookt behynd,
Lookt deadly dull, and stared as astound;
They lookt about, but no where could espie
He lookt a little further, and espyde
Lookt on them louely, still in stedfast state,
But passed forth, and lookt still forward right,
Lookt foorth, as Phoebus face out of the east,
But he on it lookt scornefully askew,
And as she lookt about, she did behold,
He lookt askew with his mistrustfull eyes,
He glad of life, that lookt for death but late,
But lookt on Glauce grim, who woxe afeard
Who lookt a little vp at that his speech,
Then when she long had lookt vpon each one,
Then when she lookt about, and nothing found
To all, that on him lookt without good heed,
Nor good nor bad, ne euer lookt aside,
Whom when they heard so say, they lookt about,
Lookt vp with eyes full sad and hart full sore;
But when he lookt about on euery syde,
But being vp, he lookt againe aloft,
With drearie drouping eyne lookt vp like one aghast.
For not with arras made in painefull loome,
A laesie loord, for nothing good to donne,
Besides the losse of so much loos and fame,
The lothfull life, now loosd from sinfull bands,
He reard him vp, and loosd his yron bands,
Hath loosd her helmet from her lofty hed,
The God of warre, she from her middle loosd,
For euer as they fastned it, it loos'd
Hauing through stirring loosd their wonted band,
Eftsoones he loosd that Squire, and so him left,
That soone to loose her wicked bands did her constraine.
Now a loose Leman to vile seruice bound:
Disdaind to loose the meed he wonne in fray,
To Therion, a loose vnruly swayne;
Did loose his vele by chaunce, and open flew:
As for loose loues they are vaine, and vanish into nought.
Striuing to loose the knot, that fast him tyes,
And stroue to loose the farre infixed sting:
To loose, ne yet the warlike pledge to yield,
Was giuen all to lust and loose liuing,
Mingled emongst loose Ladies and lasciuious boyes.
led into loose desire,
Her light behauiour, and loose dalliaunce
In her loose lap, it softly to sustaine,
Doth loose his dignitie and natiue grace.
The traine whereof loose far behind her strayd,
Gathered the Princes of the people loose,
Their king, and swore him fealty to win or loose.
With hoarie lockes all loose, and visage grim;
Her to rebuke, for being loose and light:
And garments loose, that seemd vnmeet for womanhed.
To loose long gotten honour with one euill hond.
And loath'd the loose demeanure of that wanton sort.
To loose her warlike limbs and strong effort,
Where so loose life, and so vngentle trade
Now loose about her shoulders hong vndight,
She was asham'd to be so loose surprized,
Be ouertaken. Soone her garments loose
And her loose lockes to dight in order dew,
Which with her loose incontinence doth blend
Both was he loth to loose his loued Dame,
The gentle Lady, loose at randon left,
And coy lookes tempring with loose dalliance;
To let him loose, to saue their proper stakes;
There might ye see loose steeds at randon ronne,
But it would loose, or else a sunder teare.
And loose affections streightly to restraine;
And eke too loose of life, and eke of loue too light.
The course of loose affection to forstall,
Loose so immortall glory, and so endlesse gaines.
The wanton Lee, that oft doth loose his way,
He where he list goes loose, and laughes at me.
So euer loose, so euer happy be.
But where so loose or happy that thou art,
Ne loose that he hath bound with stedfast band.
Amongst loose Ladies, lapped in delight:
Now scratching her, and her loose locks misusing;
And therefore loth to loose her right away,
With locks all loose, and rayment all to rent;
Could euer loose, but suffred deadly doole.
To loose his shield, and long while did contend:
To loose the badge, that should his deedes display.
Hung loose and loathsomely: Thereto her hew
He could him force to loose, or leaue his enterprize.
Wherewith the beast enrag'd to loose his pray,
Subdue desire, and bridle loose delight,
That forst him th'halter from his hand to loose,
Those villeins vew'd with loose lasciuious sight,
They that haue much, feare much to loose thereby,
The heardes out of their foldes were loosed quight,
His wanton dayes that euer loosely led,
Her golden lockes for haste were loosely shed
Full of disport, still laughing, loosely light,
About her shoulders weren loosely shed,
Grew all afore, and loosely hong vnrold,
Euery of which did loosely disaray
Loosely disperst with puffe of euery blast:
Of louers loosely knit, where list them to repaire.
Caught her thus loosely wandring here and there,
Loosely displayd vpon the grassie ground,
Whom when as Turpin saw so loosely layd,
She in the open fields had loosely layd
Who in her loosenesse tooke exceeding ioy;
Or loosenesse, that she lightly did remoue.
With loosenesse of her loue, and loathly deed,
Ne would his looser life be tide to law,
Vpstarted lightly from his looser make,
Of looser life, and heat of hardiment,
Her looser golden lockes he rudely rent,
Was lightnesse seene, or looser vanitie,
In breaded tramels, that no looser heares
Which spent their looser daies in lewd delights,
His looser garment to the ground did fall,
Her looser notes with Lydian harmony;
Nought so of loue this looser Dame did skill,
My looser rimes (I wote) doth sharply wite,
But layd aside, when so she vsd her looser sport.
And looser thoughts to lawfull bounds withdraw;
Whose looser thought will lightly be misled,
To thrall my looser life, or my last bale to breed.
Both loosers lot, and victours prayse alsoe.
But loosing soone his shield, did it forgoe,
Pourd out in loosnesse on the grassy grownd,
Whose shadie boughes sharpe steele did neuer lop,
The deare remembrance of his dying Lord,
Of highest God, the Lord of life and light;
In hast vnto his Lord, where he him left afore.
And said, Ah Sir, my liege Lord and my loue,
My dearest Lord fell from high honours staire,
The Lyon Lord of euerie beast in field,
But he my Lyon, and my noble Lord,
And weeping said, Ah my long lacked Lord,
He now Lord of the field, his pride to fill,
Old loues, and warres for Ladies doen by many a Lord.
Ah dearest Lord (quoth she) how might that bee,
Where haue you left your Lord, that could so well you tosse?
In which my Lord my liege doth lucklesse lie,
And twixt him and his Lord did like a bulwarke stand.
To her yeeld passage, gainst his Lord to goe,
So brought vnto his Lord, as his deserued pray.
For she it is, that did my Lord bethrall,
My dearest Lord, and deepe in dongeon lay,
She said, Ah dearest Lord, what euill starre
But welcome now my Lord, in wele or woe,
And you, my Lord, the Patrone of my life,
Of that deare Lord, who oft thereon was fownd,
And to his Lord and Ladie lowd gan call,
That aged Sire, the Lord of all that land,
Forth came that auncient Lord and aged Queene,
Their Lord and Patrone loud did him proclame,
That auncient Lord gan fit occasion finde,
Ah dearest Lord, said then that doughty knight,
My Lord, my King, be nought hereat dismayd,
O pardon me, my soueraigne Lord, to show
And cryde, Mercie Sir knight, and mercie Lord,
My Lord my loue; my deare Lord, my deare loue,
My Lord my loue; my deare Lord, my deare loue,
My lifest Lord she thus beguiled had;
How that my Lord from her I would repriue,
Ye bene right hard amated, gratious Lord,
O fly from wrath, fly, O my liefest Lord:
Hold, ï¿½ deare Lord, hold your dead-doing hand,
And when he felt the folly of his Lord,
Certes, my Lord, (said he) that shall I soone,
But loe my Lord, my liege, whose warlike name,
My Lord (quoth he) me sent, and streight behight
(Said Guyon,) let that message to thy Lord be brought.
When late he saw his Lord in heauy plight,
Turnd to the shore, where that same warlike Lord
Art Lord, and eke of nature Soueraine,
Whom should he, but his owne deare Lord, there see,
His owne deare Lord Pyrrochles, in sad plight,
To see my Lord so deadly damnifyde
Into the lake he lept, his Lord to ayd,
The carefull seruant, striuing with his raging Lord.
To saue my Lord, in wretched plight forlore;
And to be Lord of those, that riches haue,
Till that him thus bespake their soueraigne Lord & sire.
Deliuered vp the Lord of life to die,
The same to thee, against his lord to fight,
My Lord, my liege, by whose most gratious ayd
Said Guyon, Noble Lord, what meed so great,
And many a Lord of noble parentage,
And Locrine left chiefe Lord of Britany.
Locrine was left the soueraine Lord of all;
What time th'eternall Lord in fleshly slime
Perswaded him to ceasse, and her Lord to relent.
Least that his Lord they should behind inuade;
Who was the Lord of Mathrauall by right,
But shall with gifts his Lord Cadwallin pacify.
Late King, now captiue, late Lord, now forlorne,
That shortly he a great Lord did appeare,
That Ladies loue vnto his Lord forlent,
For whiles his Lord pursewd that noble Mayd,
Else shall thy louing Lord thee see no more,
Mercy deare Lord (said he) what grace is this,
Which first was spoken by th'Almightie lord,
Against that Castles Lord they gan conspire,
And bad before his soueraine Lord appere:
And you most noble Lord, that can and dare
My Lord and I will search the wide forrest.
He said; ï¿½ soueraigne Lord that sit'st on hye,
Or hast thou, Lord, of good mens cause no heed?
That her liues Lord and patrone of her health
Whose Lord hath done my loue this foule despight?
That when the wicked feend his Lord tormented,
There Satyrane Lord of the field he found,
To be his loue, and take him for her Lord,
Daughter vnto a Lord of high degree;
His owne deare Lord Prince Arthure came that way,
And eke all mindlesse of his owne deare Lord
And howld aloud to see his Lord there slaine,
To him, as to their Lord, and tribute pay:
So brought vnto his Lord, where he did sit,
And shew'd, that with his Lord she would emparlaunce make.
So he them streight conducted to his Lord,
To reskew his owne Lord, but thought it iust t'obay.
And of her seruant make her souerayne Lord:
And where is he thy Lord, and how far hence?
My Lord, your Loue, by hard mishap doth lie
Which had her Lord in her base prison pent,
To see her Lord, that was reported drent,
Ah my deare Lord, what sight is this (quoth she)
Meane while her noble Lord sir Artegall
Before directed by his Lord; to th'end
And to his Lord Sir Artegall it lent,
To be my loue, and take me for her Lord,
And him adoring as her liues deare Lord,
For she was daughter to a noble Lord,
Vnlesse that with his Lord he formerly did fight.
But yet aread to me, how hight thy Lord,
The groome went streight way in, and to his Lord
The wife of bold Sir Bruin, who is Lord
So is my Lord now seiz'd of all the land,
But most my Lord is grieued herewithall,
Or deare aby, for why his Lord of old
Those euill tidings to their Lord to shew.
As to his Lord, and downe his weapons layd,
Which lately sought his Lord for to displease:
The whyles his Lord in siluer slomber lay,
Backe to the place, whereas his Lord he sleeping vew'd.
The Squire him selfe when as he saw his Lord,
Soone as they spide her, Lord what gladfull glee
Whereof was Lord the good Sir Bellamoure;
The Lord of Many Ilands, farre renound
Thence running forth vnto her loued Lord,
Of Lordes and Ladies stood on euery side
Her Lordes and Ladies all this while deuise
Soone after which, three hundred Lordes he slew
Then listen Lordings, if ye list to weet
And Lordings curbe, that commons ouer-aw;
Vnder his Lordly foot him proudly hath supprest.
And launcht his Lordly hart: with death opprest
Proud Tarquin, and too lordly Lentulus,
The wide kingdome of loue with Lordly sway,
And strong as Lyon in his Lordly might.
They doe thy linage, and thy Lordly brood;
Ah puissaunt Lords, what cursed euill Spright,
Be therefore, O my deare Lords, pacifide,
Ah well away, most noble Lords, how can
His Lords owne flesh. Therewith out of his hond
But swaruing from the marke, his Lords life did assure.
Ladies and Lords she euery where mote heare
Kings Queenes, Lords Ladies, Knights & Damzels gent
And wondrous chast of life, yet lou'd of Knights & Lords.
Full many Lords, and many Knights her loued,
And squiers make hast to helpe their Lords fordonne.
That many Lords haue her to wife desired:
Of Lords and Ladies infinite great store;
So were they left Lords of the field alone:
Faire Lords and Ladies, which about you dwell,
Into his Lords forbidden hall to passe.
And eke of Lordship, with both land and fee:
Of all her land and lordship during life:
Vntill the loue of Lordship and of lands
Now loath great Lordship and ambition;
Hauing great Lordships got and goodly farmes,
She was in life and euery vertuous lore,
Trew sacred lore, which from her sweet lips did redound.
There all my dayes he traind me vp in vertuous lore.
Renowmd throughout the world for sacred lore,
By hearing her, and by her sisters lore,
In vertuous lore to traine his tender youth,
Most noble Virgin, that by fatall lore
The warlike minds, to learne her goodly lore,
Yet he his mothers lore did well retaine,
In leaches craft, by great Appolloes lore,
In all the lore of loue, and goodly womanhead.
Ne was she ignoraunt of that lewd lore,
But hearken to his lore, and all his counsell hyde.
But yet, if please ye listen to my lore,
Neither of them she found where she them lore:
Entrayled mutually in louely lore,
And lawlesse lust to rule with reasons lore;
Stood still by him astonisht at his lore,
Of vertue and of ciuill vses lore,
Artegall trayn'd in Iustice lore
For that to her he seem'd best skild in righteous lore.
My law, and euer to my lore be bound;
Right in their wrongs, are rul'd by righteous lore
They heare him not, they haue forgot his lore,
Vnto that Lady, where he her had lore,
Bad him auaunt, ne would vnto his lore
Thy courteous lore, that doest my loue deride,
Or noursle vp in lore of learn'd Philosophy.
Backe to the place, where Turpine late he lore;
Her wisedome did admire, and hearkned to her loring.
Who after that he had faire Vna lorne,
But first him losde, and afterwards thus to him saide.
Or soone to lose, before he once would lin;
To get, and nightly feare to lose his owne,
In feare to lose his weapon in his paw,
Vp in one knot, he low adowne did lose:
That wanton Ladie, with her louer lose,
But wishing it far off, his idle wish doth lose.
Abroad thy fresh youthes fairest flowre, but lose
He mote surcease his suit, and lose the hope
Madnesse to saue a part, and lose the whole.
And lose the teme out of his weary waine,
And an earth-quake, as if it streight would lose
And sayd, her loue to lose she was full loth,
As all men do, that lose the liuing spright:
Whom he that hath, were loth to lose so light,
(For so to lose a Lady, were great shame)
For glorie vaine their fellowship to lose,
But it would lose or breake, that many had disgrast.
And rather had to lose, then trie in armes his right.
Great shame to lose so long employed paines,
Till she had sau'd so many loues, as she did lose.
Whether I shall you leaue, or from these villaines lose.
The whiles a losell wandring by the way,
And to the boaster said; Thou losell base,
And let that losell, plainely now displayd,
